title: 108_s1932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Artists' Rights and Theft Prevention Act of 2004" or the "ART Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that intellectual property is crucial for innovation and economic development, deserving protection under the law. Music, film, software, and other forms of intellectual property are vital sectors of the US economy. Intellectual property is a significant sector of the US economy, accounting for over 5% of GDP in 2001, nearly 6% of all US employment, and leading in foreign sales and exports. This sector is facing challenges from illegal reproduction and distribution facilitated by the Internet and technology. The No Electronic Theft (NET) Act was passed in 1997 to combat illegal reproduction and distribution of copyrighted materials facilitated by the Internet and technology. It allows prosecution of individuals involved in large-scale infringement cases where the infringers act willfully. The No Electronic Theft (NET) Act's economic harm requirement makes investigations of copyright infringements resource-intensive. To deter egregious violations, recognizing economic harm from distributing prerelease commercial works is crucial. The use of camcorders for recording is also a concern. The distribution of prerelease commercial works can cause significant economic harm. Camcorders used in movie theaters to make illegal copies of films are a serious threat to the industry, with 92.4 percent of first copies available for download originating from camcorders. Online theft of music, film, software, and intellectual property is on the rise, posing enforcement challenges. The negative impact of online theft on intellectual property industries, such as music and film, is significant, with a 31 percent drop in music industry sales from 2000 to 2003. Federal legislation is needed to address this issue due to its detrimental effects on the economy. The United States economy is impacted by the importance of intellectual property industries like music, film, and software, as outlined in Article 1, section 8 of the Constitution. The importance of music, film, software, and other intellectual property industries to the US economy is significant, with theft and unauthorized distribution occurring regularly across state and international lines. Criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater are addressed in Section 3. Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code, criminalizes unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater. Offenders face up to 3 years in prison, fines, or both. The unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater is a criminal offense under Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code. Offenders can face imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both. For subsequent offenses, the penalty can be up to 6 years of imprisonment, fines, or both. Additionally, upon conviction, the court may order the forfeiture and destruction of all unauthorized copies of protected works. The unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater is a criminal offense under Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code. Offenders can face imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both. For subsequent offenses, the penalty can be up to 6 years of imprisonment, fines, or both. Upon conviction, the court may order the forfeiture and destruction of all unauthorized copies of protected works, along with any related equipment used in the offense. Authorized investigative, protective, or intelligence activities are exempt from this section, as well as theaters exhibiting motion pictures with reasonable cause. "(d) Immunity for Theaters.--Owners, employees, or licensors of theaters can detain suspected violators of unauthorized recording laws for questioning without liability in civil or criminal actions. (e) Victim Impact Statement." Owners, employees, or licensors of theaters can detain suspected violators of unauthorized recording laws without liability. Victims of the offense can submit a victim impact statement during the preparation of the presentence report. Victims of the offense can submit a victim impact statement detailing the extent of injury and loss, including the economic impact on the victim. The statement should include producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate works affected by the offense. Definitions for this section are provided. In this section, definitions for terms such as `audiovisual work', `copy', `copyright owner', `motion picture', `motion picture exhibition facility', and `transmit' are provided. The term `audiovisual recording device' is defined as any technology capable of recording or transmitting copyrighted motion pictures. The curr_chunk discusses the prohibition of using technology to record or transmit copyrighted motion pictures. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections in the United States Code. The curr_chunk introduces the definition of "motion picture exhibition facility" and criminal infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution. The curr_chunk introduces an amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, regarding criminal infringement of copyright for commercial gain through reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code addresses criminal infringement of copyright for commercial gain through reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works valued at over $1,000 or intended for commercial distribution on a computer network accessible to the public. The definition of 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' in copyright law includes computer programs, musical works, motion pictures, and sound recordings with a reasonable expectation of commercial distribution. The definition of 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' in copyright law includes works that have not been commercially distributed yet, such as motion pictures that have been shown in theaters but not released for sale to the public. The amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code, expands criminal penalties for individuals who distribute copyrighted works outside of movie theaters. The amendment expands criminal penalties for distributing copyrighted works outside of movie theaters, including imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both. The amendment increases penalties for copyright infringement under section 506(a)(1)(C) of title 17, with imprisonment up to 10 years, fines, or both for repeat offenses. The amendment increases penalties for copyright infringement under section 506(a)(1)(C) of title 17, with imprisonment up to 10 years, fines, or both for repeat offenses. The term 'financial gain' and 'work being prepared for commercial' are defined in the amendment. The amendment defines 'financial gain' and 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' for copyright infringement penalties under section 506(a)(1)(C) of title 17. Civil remedies are available for infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution under section 5. Preregistration procedures for works being prepared for commercial distribution will be established by the Register of Copyrights within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. This will allow preregistration for works in specific classes determined by the Register. The Register of Copyrights will establish preregistration procedures for works with a history of infringement before authorized distribution. Applicants must submit an application, deposit, and fee within 3 months of first publication to avoid dismissal of infringement actions. An action for infringement under this chapter will be dismissed, and no statutory damages or attorney fees will be awarded for a preregistered work if required items are not submitted to the Copyright Office within 3 months of first publication or 1 month after the copyright owner learns of the infringement. Section 411(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include "preregistration or" before the institution of infringement actions. Section 412 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to exclude actions for infringement of preregistered works before the infringement occurs. Federal sentencing guidelines are addressed in Section 6. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes within 180 days of this Act. This includes offenses under specific sections of title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The United States Sentencing Commission may amend Federal sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes under specific sections of title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The Commission must ensure appropriate measures are taken in this process. The United States Sentencing Commission must ensure that Federal sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes are stringent and reflective of the nature of the offenses. They should consider providing a sentencing enhancement for those convicted of unauthorized display, performance, publication, reproduction, or distribution of copyrighted works. The United States Sentencing Commission should assess if the current guidelines adequately address the unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works over the Internet. The United States Sentencing Commission should evaluate if current guidelines for copyright infringement reflect harm to victims when the extent of reproduction or distribution is unknown. Authorization of appropriations of $5,000,000 for the Department of Justice for fiscal years 2005-2009 to prosecute violations of intellectual property rights under specified sections of the United States Code.
